Award.AwardTitle: REU Site in Chemistry at the University of Connecticut
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site led by Christian Brueckner at the University of Connecticut. The research projects supported in this site are in a wide range of areas of chemistry. Undergraduates will be recruited to this site from regional colleges and universities that lack opportunities for undergraduate research. The site will continue a fruitful collaboration with students and faculty from Central Connecticut State University. The site will support eight undergraduate research students per summer in a ten week program. A sample of the projects that researchers will work on include: (1) the synthesis and study of protein-based (bacteriorhodopsin and variants) photovoltaic devices; (2) the synthesis of interesting pyrrole-modified porphyrins; (3) the synthesis and study of shape-memory polymer materials; (4) the development of biocatalytic nanomaterials for chemical applications; (5) the study of the many roles and mechanisms of carotenoids in photosynthetic processes; and (6) the study of the conversion of biomass into useful fuels and chemicals. In addition to conducting research during the summer, the students participating in this program will participate in a number of professional development activities, including training in scientific ethics and communication.

Young scientists need exposure to modern research methods and tools as part of their training. This REU site aims to provide students without significant research experience a chance to conduct cutting-edge research in the chemical sciences with dedicated faculty mentors at this major university. The diverse student cohort participating in research at this site will be well-prepared for further study in the chemical sciences, and graduate school, with eventual employment as part of the country's technical workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Department of Chemistry at the UConn continued its thriving NSF REU program. The program spanned four years, commencing in 2011. A total of 29 highly motivated sophomore/junior/senior undergraduates, all from non-Ph.D. granting institutions were selected from ~600 completed applications to participate in graduate level research projects of their choice. Students from institutions with limited opportunities for independent research, women, and under-represented groups were especially encouraged to apply (30% of our cohort were minority students; 65% female). A unique thrust was placed on the inclusion of non-traditional under­graduates from nearby Central Connecticut State University (CCSU).

The research was conducted for 10 weeks in the summer in our new chemistry facility. The REU students interacted extensively with their faculty research mentors. While the core aim of this program was to introduce the students to the full breadth of research-related activities, a number of ancillary professional development offerings and social events rounded out the experience. Up to eight seminars intro­duced the students to topics such as safe practices in the labora­tories, how to present research results effectively, ethical issues in science, careers in chemistry, and scientific writing exercises. A full-day event were hands-on workshops on single crystal X-ray crystallography, held at CCSU. This short course, involving the entire cohort, introduced an intellectually challenging technical component and that provided the students a good visual and conceptual idea about this technique that is instrumental to all fields of chemistry. Another highlight of our ancillary program was a guided tour of a regional industrial research facility.

A seminar series was used as a community building component and a platform for presenting technical, professional and ethical issues of long-term importance. Seminar or workshop titles were, for example, “Chemical Hygiene Training” , the “The Ethics of Research”, “Responsible Conduct of Research”, “Giving an Effective Research Presentation”, “Graduate Studies in Chemistry” , or “Diversity Panel Discussion”.

Our REU program benefited from strong interactions with the other campus REU programs (Physiology and Neurobiology, Electrical and Computer Engineering and the proposed REU programs in Pharmaceutical Sciences, Polymer Chemistry, and Molecular and Cell Biology, and the NEAGEP program). All campus REU programs coordinated their recruiting strategies, all students were housed together, and they shared social and scientific events (ethics workshop, final poster session, etc.). The UConn REU programs culminated in oral presentations and poster symposia for which the University community, parents and faculty from the students' home institutions were invited. The program was assessed using the Undergraduate Research Student Self-Assessment (URSSA) survey instrument, and a multi-year follow-up program was in place to assure that the goals of the REU program are met.

The key intellectual merit of the proposed activity was the exposure of students that had previously no or limited research experiences to a stimulating graduate-level research program promoted their pursuit of a career in the sciences. 

The broader impact of the proposed activities was to expose our participants to a broad range of state-of-the-art chemical research.
